Edward Jessup.Action: Analyzes detailed encephalographic evidence and notes specific brain wave patterns during sensory deprivation experiments.
Presents a calm, focused, monastic demeanor while observing experimental data.
Finds the encephalographic evidence especially interesting and draws comparisons between EEG patterns and those of Zen priests.
Decides to personally try the sensory deprivation tank experience after reviewing the data, indicating initiative and confidence.

Successfully undergoes a prolonged and intense sensory deprivation experiment, maintaining composure and reporting detailed hallucinatory experiences.
Removes EEG leads and exits tank calmly, engages in casual, matter-of-fact conversation showing awareness of the experiment duration and effects.
Rummages through data carefully, puts on glasses to study EEG tracings, reviews detailed notes and discusses observed reactions with Rosenberg.
Admits uncertainty about what they are looking for and acknowledges limited literature on the subject; expresses intention to create sensible methodology in a largely unexplored field.

Seated quietly, appears distracted and somewhat out of things.

Engages in a light, somewhat self-deprecating exchange about his eccentricity and their intimate relationship.
